The second example is the theatre museum that forms part of the Georgian Theatre Royal. Volunteers staff the museum, which receives almost no public money. Many small museums are in the same position. It does not seem likely that that pattern will change, except at the margins. We need to keep it in mind during any sophistication of the DCMS/MLA regime.

I shall now deal with governance. Following the National Heritage Act 1983, most national museums are incorporated as trusts under statute. The Bowes Museum Trust is modelled on the 1983 Act. Goodison found that that structure was appropriate and, in his eighth recommendation, asked that MLA make available a summary of the means by which trusts were set up, their agreements for continued local authority or other public funding, and their experience as independent entities. Goodison argued that independent trusts could recruit members to museum boards with a wide range of management and fundraising skills, as well as knowledge of collections. He also saw independent trust status as releasing energy and enthusiasm. Has Goodison's eighth recommendation been accepted, or will it be? If so, when will it be implemented?

I shall comment on good governance. Governing bodies clearly need to understand their accountability under both charity and company law and accounting standards. They need to understand the strengths of their collections because the public is the No. 1 stakeholder, and boards need to know how their professional staff will market their collections to bring in visitors. That is a different issue from accessibility, most notably from access for the disabled, which always needs its own detailed attention. Accessibility will be in museums' business plans, as will marketing and income generation. Bringing those strands together, a board's central judgments will be at what level of activity the museum will be sustainable, and whether the board is confident that it will hand on the museum and its collections in a better state than that in which it found them.

There is time for two other matters today. The first is social inclusion. MORI found that only a very small percentage of respondents cited exclusion. Many more, in a ratio of 25:1, cited lack of time or lack of interest. That presents museums with an opportunity in competition with all the other attractive choices open to the public. Inclusion is very much in their interests, for the more people who visit the better. Given that MORI also found that four out of five people supported having a local museum, the market has growth potential.

Enjoyment and education remain the key to that growth. If visitors leave with a smile having learnt something, the word gets round. The young are of great assistance, whether in school parties or family groups. They not only enjoy themselves and learn, but lighten the atmosphere and do much to make our grander Victorian buildings more friendly. Other assets help, such as a good cafe and an interesting shop. After 90 minutes in a museum, anybody needs a strong cup of tea. To me, the defining business characteristic of a successful museum—learning from private houses open to the public—is increasing numbers of visitors and increasing self-generated funds.

I return to The Value of Museums and its 13 questions. They are mostly about process. One question asks what role government should play. In it and other documents, there is talk of a national strategy, of national methods of measurement, and for museums to achieve coherence and coherent advocacy for all. Does it make sense to include the National Gallery and the Grace Darling Museum in Northumberland in a national strategy common to all? It is always the wish of the official mind to tidy up—to say with a sigh of relief, "Now we have only one body that speaks for museums"—and publish pest control best practice forgetting that a front-line professional has just found a better way of dealing with the carpet beetle in her textile collection.

How then can government help while giving up their controlling instinct—their wish, suppressed I suppose, to centralise? By far the most help to collections comes from tax breaks. The present tax regime is helpful. Goodison recommended further assistance, which is another reason why the review deserves attention. As to all else, whether it be links to further and higher education, a strong research culture or being responsive to open communities, Value is pushing at an open door. Perhaps the Government will recognise that, if they will the ends but do not want to provide all the means, they need to pause and think deeply about priorities and sustainability.

Even if Renaissance in the Regions is rolled out for the whole country, may the Bowes's most useful but modest 12.5 per cent of total income be remembered? Will the Government also remember that, for donors, benefactors and volunteers, process is not that important but that trust in forward plans is crucial?

I am looking for the Minister to tell the House that the Government are not going down the prescriptive, centralising route, but rather will adopt a light-handed, enabling approach to museum strategy and its implementation. Will he also arrange to bring back "enjoyment" alongside the education? I beg to move for Papers.

My Lords, it gives me great pleasure to follow the noble Viscount and to congratulate him on securing this debate and for giving such an excellent speech in describing in relatively few words the profound effect for good that museums have on our society. Indeed, they contribute so much and in so many different ways, that it is not possible to cover all of the ground in a single speech this afternoon.

I hope, therefore, that your Lordships will forgive me if I concentrate mainly on two museums that I know particularly well—the National Railway Museum in York and its newly opened branch at Shildon in south-west Durham known as Locomotion. Many of the examples that I shall quote about those museums are representative of the excellent work going on across the museum world. In doing so, I declare an unpaid interest, as chairman of the Railway Heritage Committee.

I plan to cover four main areas: education, social regeneration, heritage preservation, and sustainability. I shall start with education. The traditional educational benefits of museums are well known, but few people realise how comprehensively museum education now links into the national educational agenda at all levels, from nursery to postgraduate work. For example, in York over the past three years, the education programme has included working in partnership with the Sure Start initiative, York's Learning City early education programme, the Learning and Skills Council and York Family Learning.

In 2004 the National Railway Museum opened the Yorkshire Rail Academy, a new educational institution for rail-related studies for the rail industry and for students in the 16–19 education bracket—and the first rail centre of vocational excellence in Britain. This work is in addition to the well-established Institute of Railway Studies and Transport History, which offers undergraduate and postgraduate teaching in the history of transport.

Current projects at York include Creative Minds, which aims to promote science, maths and technology in schools and the Initial Teacher Training project, a research project to investigate the possibilities for museums, libraries and archives to have trainee teachers spending some of their placements at MLAs. Speaking of the MLAs, I commend their council's Renaissance project, which seeks to raise standards at over 40 regional museums, encouraging good practice, reaching new users, particularly among groups that have not traditionally visited museums—40 per cent of new users came from priority audiences in the scheme's first year—and improving and unlocking collections. If I had more time, I should have liked to say more about their good work.

I turn now to social regeneration. Perhaps the best example of that is the opening of Locomotion, at Shildon in September last year. It represents the first ever joint management partnership between a national museum and a local authority. It was mainly funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the European Regional Development Fund and the regional development agency, One North East.

What I believe attracted these funding bodies was the prospect that Locomotion would not only appeal to a huge range of visitors, but that it would also add to the north-east's appeal as a tourist destination. Thus, the region's economy would benefit and there would be greater awareness of the north-east's heritage and history. Since its opening, the new museum has welcomed over 130,000 visitors, has won two national awards and has been short listed for four more.

Against that background, the partnership set out to create a new museum with a real sense of community, as well as national and international status. It tapped into a rich local history through oral history recording and worked with schools and adult community arts projects. A community archive project, called Time Tracks, used special computer software at selected public venues to engage local people by recording and sharing personal reminiscence through scanned photographs and documents.

What I like about Locomotion—and this is true of so many new and modernised museums these days—is how it appeals to all members of the family. There are loads of interactive displays, which are both fun and inspirational. The days of dusty old displays in sealed cabinets with large "don't touch" signs are, happily, over.

I do not much care for the word "experience", as applied to museum days out—it seems to be applied to almost every visit anywhere—but it does describe well what parents and children can enjoy at Shildon in terms of special family events, a railway-themed children's playground, picnic areas, shops and a café. As Locomotion is part of the National Railway Museum, admission to it is free. The removal of national museum and gallery admission charges has widened access to a staggering degree. In the last year that the NRM had a full charging policy, 1998–99, 434,566 people visited the museum. Last year—the year up to March this year—the number was 885,366. That is more than twice as many as six years previously. One can imagine all multiplier benefits for the local economy that came from that increase in visitors in terms of shops, cafés, restaurants, and hotels in the region. I hope that my noble friend will be able to confirm that there is no possibility that the Government will abandon the free admissions policy.

Access is part of the third area that I wish to cover, along with heritage. In relation to that, there is a particular project for which I seek my noble friend's support. He will recall that on 9 March, during the later stages of the Railways Bill in the last Parliament, I moved an amendment which sought to require the Secretary of State to come to an agreement with the trustees of the Science Museum to ensure the provision of a place of deposit for records generated within the railway industry.

The amendment was necessary, because while the national archives at Kew house a record of Britain's railways from their inception to the mid-1990s, the records of the industry since railway privatisation have had no place of deposit because they are not public records. I said in that debate that the Railway Heritage Committee strongly supported the setting up of a railway industry national archive and wanted to see it based at the NRM in York. The NRM is keen to oblige and is ready to provide the space necessary as part of a broader project that greatly enhances public access for its existing archive and library collections.

I acknowledge with thanks the support of the noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave of North Hill, from whom we shall have the pleasure of hearing later in this debate. He wrote a most helpful letter, which I put on record in Committee on that Bill.

The National Railway Museum is currently seeking funding for a project known as Search Engine to improve the storage of and access to the museum's extensive library, archive and image collections. Funding has already been secured from the Higher Education Funding Council, DCMS and internal fundraising, and the final element of the cost is being requested from the Heritage Lottery Fund to provide the appropriate improvements to public access. Currently, there is a funding gap of some £1.5 million for the development of the repository. I hope that we may obtain from my noble friend more encouragement than he was able to provide on 9 March.

Finally, I shall briefly mention two aspects of railway museum life that your Lordships may find surprising. The first is the Africa initiative. The NRM has helped establish the first railway museum in Sierra Leone, which is that country's second national museum, by giving museum training to young volunteers from Freetown. That is proving to be of huge benefit to a country which is only just recovering from civil war—and is an example of the outreach approach that our museums can offer.

Secondly, there is a commitment to sustainable development. I am pleased that the noble Viscount referred to that, too. One of the guiding principles at the new Locomotion museum has been environmental sustainability. The museum is built on a former brownfield site and is designed to have a reduced impact on the environment through a host of innovative sustainable features such as storage of rainwater for use in locomotive boilers, a wind turbine to provide electricity that pumps water from the underground store, many recycled materials such as rail sleepers and tracks, on-site transport by a green fuel bus, and—I cannot resist this one—provision of a special habitat to encourage the endangered Dingy Skipper butterfly.

I hope that I have succeeded in demonstrating not only the intrinsic value of our museums, but also the fact that museums such as the National Railway Museum and its parent organisation, the National Museums of Science and Industry, succeed brilliantly in spanning the worlds of arts and science, particularly in terms of government interests such as the DTI science and innovation strategy through to regeneration, sustainable transport and overseas initiatives.

It is a record of which they, and we as a nation, can feel justly proud. I hope that makes us all the more determined to ensure that the resources remain available to them to do in future what they already do so well today.

My Lords, when I saw the topic of this debate and decided to put my name down to speak to it, I was inspired by something that the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, mentioned: memories of enjoying museums. In my earliest years in my home city of Norwich, people went to the Castle Museum. How positive that had been was brought home to me a few years ago when, having returned to live in Norwich, I gave a dinner party. The guests were mainly ageing bumped and banged rugby players and their wives and the conversation was mainly "Do you remember when we almost won that trophy?" stories. But we found ourselves talking about how, as children, we had enjoyed going to the local museum.

It was an institution that people—children—could go to, enjoy and get something out of. Everyone had a favourite exhibit—perhaps the now terribly politically incorrect collection of stuffed animals or the small boy's dream, the large, heavy bits of metal used for cutting people's heads off—but occasionally one would notice another item in passing, one of the paintings, or the pottery and the bits of social history attached to it. On the way to the gruesome natural or political history, one would pick up information. It was a safe and reassuring environment and allowed people to stop, look and think about things, at least in private.

Not only was this revelation by a group of increasingly middle-aged men a surprise to their wives, it was also quite a relief. It was not a standard conversation but I use it as an example to find my jumping-off point, which is that we cannot quantify the value of museums of all types, other than to say that it is there in itself. The fact that people are not always going to museums does not mean to say that we should disregard them if they do not get enough throughput. There are very good small museums. I remember one at Dunwich on the Suffolk coast. It is a record of a town that is rapidly falling into the sea. It has won numerous awards and I was very inspired by it. Making something like that relevant is a great achievement because it tells one about something of which only the bones are left behind but which can attract one's attention.

In the current environment, when about one-third of all television programmes that are not reality TV seem to be about history, we can encourage more people to look at the artefacts and get more information about them. As the noble Lord, Lord Faulkner, said, great rows of huge cabinets with lists underneath them and signs saying, "Do not touch" are disappearing. Occasionally when I see displays like that a warm glow comes over me and I think, "Those were the days". Museums are increasingly being used to show people that there are other things to learn and look at and that is a very good thing. Everything has a history, even science and technology, and it has a point, and it has a value for studying the present. The history of science is probably one of the best ways of looking at the future of science, at least of having an idea of where to jump off from.

We must encourage people. We must encourage museums and other bodies to be user-friendly so that people can enjoy going into them. It must be a pleasant experience. The Government, and local government, have an on-going commitment to make sure that we do this. If we do not manage to support museums, huge parts of our heritage, and the heritage industry, are in great danger of discovering that they are no longer fashionable. The density of media coverage means that it could suddenly be decided that the public has had enough of it.

We must build on what we are doing now, build up museums and similar institutions and make sure that we allow museums to be constantly available to us in a reinvented form. Calling them all museums could well be a mistake and they should possibly be given a new title or be slightly reinvented, but I can see a new industry being invented as I speak. Interactive screens are still a comparative novelty, at least to the parents taking children around museums at the moment, but anything with a button is probably now rather boring to a child. We can invest in new structures in the way we train and progress.

This has a scholastic element, as a museum should have all its material, not just that part of it on display, open to scholars to study and learn from. The flipside of getting rid of the large display case may be that people may study a single text or artefact more closely. We must make sure that we can see artefacts and have them explained properly so that people can study and learn from them. Perhaps we can have a book or programme available so that people pay attention to the artefact in future.

Only the Government have the capacity to make sure that we can encourage and reinvest, and can be there when history is no longer popular, or not as popular as it is now. Only with support and ongoing commitment—from other political parties as well as the Government—when archaeologists digging trenches are no longer regarded as prime-time television can we be sure that what is available now will be available in future and will be at least as good and as deep.

My Lords, it is a great pleasure to follow the noble Lord, Lord Addington, as he touched on one of the central themes of the museum of which I have the privilege to be the chairman—unpaid, like the noble Lord, Lord Faulkner, is of the Railway Heritage Committee—namely, the National Museum of Science and Industry. I return to the eloquent and much appreciated speech about children and the National Railway Museum made by the noble Lord, Lord Faulkner. We are a family of museums made up of the Science Museum in south Kensington, the National Museum of Photography, Film & Television in Bradford and the railway museum with its new and splendid out-station at Shildon, to which the noble Lord, Lord Faulkner, has paid such tribute. It has been a great advantage to the National Railway Museum to have his expert help.

I join the noble Lord in saying that the achievements by Locomotion at Shildon, which is in a highly deprived region, have been outstanding. The partnership that has been built with the local authority is remarkable. The effect on the local community is already astounding. My noble friend Lord Eccles—whom I congratulate and thank for instituting the debate—touched on the economics of museums and their power to create jobs and wealth in this country. A study by McKinsey stated that in its first year Tate Modern generated economic activity worth £100 million. I shall not claim activity of that scale for Shildon, but, proportionately, I almost would. New investment is coming to that deprived town. For the first time for many years there is talk of new housing there, of other investment and of people concentrating again on Shildon. That has been done in a positive way—not looking backwards—because of the effect of that museum on bringing in people. Already it has more than doubled the projected visitor numbers that it had in its first year.

That is my first point and a point made eloquently in the National Museum Directors' Conference report of last year. It is a major industry. Of course, at the centre of its purpose is enjoyment as well as many other social purposes, but we must not underestimate how important it is to our national economy.

The noble Viscount mentioned correctly that there were about 2,500 museums in the country, generating 100 million visitors every year, more than go to all the country's live sporting events. Thirty-seven per cent of UK adult residents—over 17 million people—visit museums and galleries at least once a year, which is one of the highest proportions in Europe; 50 per cent of school-age children visit museums and galleries at least once a year; and a quarter of all visits are by children.

The figure is much higher for the Science Museum, although that creates one of the Science Museum's problems because, as the noble Lords, Lord Addington and Lord Faulkner, said, long gone are the days of exhibits in glass cases. We now have the most modern, beautifully designed and highly intelligent interactive exhibits that the children can use, but they also wear them out. One problem with science and technology exhibitions—the problem is not confined to them—is that our interactive exhibits suffer wear and tear that is reflected in costs.

The Minister should take great pride, as I do, in the fact that the numbers have increased hugely since the introduction of free entry. I support that policy, but there are some consequences. Having sat on the other side in another place, I know that it is easy to claim a great victory for some initiative but more difficult to produce the money to go with it. Museums that used to charge are compensated under a formula by the Government for free entry. Our compensation is at a low level, and as the policy has been much more successful than envisaged, a considerable strain has been put on our finances.

I shall talk about finance. The noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, rightly said that not everything in the sector depended on public money. I speak for none other than my own museum and board of trustees, but the great national and regional museums depend crucially on public money. Although the sector is extremely vital and full of life and initiatives at the moment, there is also a sense of growing strain in at least some of the big museums. If one looks at the numbers produced by the National Museum Directors' Conference report, one will see that in recent years in a number of the great museums, of which mine is one, the funding has not even kept up with inflation and has far from kept up with the increase in average earnings. That puts a tremendous strain on our staff and on our relations with our staff. A high proportion of our expenditure goes on our people.

There is a funding problem. It throws up unwelcome and difficult problems. The future of the Science Museum library has been much written about in the national press. It is difficult to see how we shall be able to fund, as we should, the maintenance of that world-class library on the history of science. We shall try to do our best.

I pay tribute to the department; it has plenty of knocks but perhaps not many ha'pence. I pay tribute to the permanent officials in the department and to their Ministers, who have been responsive to a request that we should have an objective look at the funding of the library and of the Science Museum to see whether something can be done about it. I pay tribute to the permanent Secretary, Sue Street, and perhaps in particular to her colleague, Richard Hartman, who deals with the museums on a day-to-day basis. They have been very helpful to us.

The issues facing the great museums are rather well dealt with. The debate is not about politics with a capital P, but I want to make a political reference. I think that it is fair to say that, at the last election, those of us who now work in the museum and arts sector gave the manifesto prize to the Conservative manifesto. It has been noted that a number of policies carried on by the last Conservative administration, in which I served, with opposition from the Labour Party, have now been adopted by the Labour Party to great acclaim. Who can complain about that? In economic terms, they have been a rather Thatcherite government—perhaps I should not use such words. To put it mildly, there has been a surprising continuity in economic policy that has been greatly to the benefit of this country.

Therefore, I suggest to the Minister that he should continue that procedure and steal the policies in the Conservatives' arts and museum manifesto to which I pay tribute. My honourable friend in another place, Mr Hugo Swire, the Member for East Devon, who knows what he is talking about on the subject, had a good deal to do with it. It contains a number of sensible suggestions, some of which have already been made by the noble Viscount. We should, for example, return to the excellent Goodison report and reconsider some of the encouragements to giving: lifetime giving on the US model might well be a point to pick out. Other aspects of that report should be used.

I was attracted by the idea of a national acquisitions fund. It is easy when in opposition to say we should spend more money; nonetheless, a national acquisitions fund would be very attractive. Our acquisitions budget in the Science Museum is tiny, although with help from many supporters such as the noble Lord, Lord Faulkner, we were able to raise money from the public, from one of the lottery funds and from private donors to buy the "Flying Scotsman", to great acclaim. We have virtually no acquisition fund. That is an idea that I hope the Government might steal from the Conservative manifesto. Even more important is the idea that we should allow museums and other arts organisations to bid for endowment from the lottery funds rather than simply adding facilities that are often difficult to fund. That seems an admirable idea.

I end with one warning and one anxiety. The Olympics bid is coming up. It would be a tremendous opportunity to showcase the British museums. It would be in London, if we were lucky enough to win the bid. There is also an anxiety about that: after Australia and Greece won their bids, the effect was to diminish funding for arts and museum programmes. I very much hope that we can be assured by the Minister that if, as most people in the country hope, we win the Olympic bid, the other small budgets in the DCMS will be well protected. It should be seen as an opportunity for south Kensington, with the prizes being given in Hyde Park. It would be wonderful to have the great museums of Britain, effectively, as part of our bid rather than for the museums to be anxious that they might suffer.

My Lords, although it is a disappointment not to be following the noble Lord, Lord Wilson of Tillyorn, it is a great pleasure to be following my noble friend Lord Waldegrave of North Hill, whose personal scope so impressively covers both science and the humanities.

I congratulate my noble friend Lord Eccles on his choice of subject, on giving us this opportunity to debate it and on his comprehensive introduction to the subject. When I was a Minister, the Bowes Museum was in danger of being an orphan of the storm and I congratulate him most warmly on the trustees' solution which has been adopted and the manner in which he chairs the trust.

I declare an interest as having been for more than a quarter of century a trustee of the Wordsworth Trust in Grasmere, which my great-grandfather founded over the period 1890 to 1891. We have had trustees at the Wordsworth Trust since 1890—for 115 years—and they have served us extremely well. I also declare an interest as the president of the British Antique Dealers Association and of the British Art Market Federation.

I have of course read the DCMS consultation document. In the context of the 21st century, I propose to draw perhaps a little more on a Ditchley conference report from January 1999 as the 20th century was drawing to a close, at which the noble Lord, Lord Armstrong of Ilminister, who is in the House today, was a participant. I want to borrow a couple of encapsulations from that conference report.

The conference came up with five elements to a generic mission for museums. First, to collect, preserve, exhibit and interpret objects; secondly, to service and educate a wide range of publics; thirdly, to remain relevant to those publics; fourthly, to promote visual literacy; and, finally, to be a repository of scholarship. As so often, those elements are more easily stated than enacted.

Let me dwell for a moment, even if probably over-telegraphically, on some of the shoals for those trying to carry them out. First, the dilemma of preservation versus access, or access versus the care of the objects, in a world where "sustainable" is a watchword. The objects are central. For those whom the objects feed and fire their imagination, the closer they can get to them the better. You can see school children in great museums often sitting on the floor fired in just that way because objects have been made directly available to them.

I sometimes wonder whether the ability to optimise direct access, which of course costs money, draws enough on the funding locked up in the budgets of the educational institutions themselves. On the other side, I hope new technology is deployed as much on preventive conservation as it is on interpretation and display.

Secondly, of course it is right that there should be different funding streams, and we have seen in higher education how breaking down the reliance on state funding has been a liberator. But when government assist this process by reducing the proportion of funding, they can create other dilemmas which militate against their own stated desires. As a single example, we all know of the massive pressure to see great exhibitions which are time limited, with institutions staying open until midnight in the final stages. Yet that pressure is in part occasioned by sponsors having, properly and necessarily, been given time and privacy earlier in the exhibition's run to invite their own guests and—I suppose I must utter the word—stakeholders to a private view.

There is another incidence of needing to look a gift horse in the mouth, as Virgil says in the Aeneid about the Trojan horse, where the expansion of media sponsorship into culture and away from their normal alliterative standbys carries the appetite to own the content, which carries its own risks, and, to mix metaphors, museums must be careful not to give away their crown jewels.

Thirdly, and analogously, museums can have too many masters. The museum professionals, being themselves interdisciplinary, may welcome this but ironically without setting priorities—to borrow from St Luke, interdisciplinarian, discipline thyself.

Fourthly, some people doubt whether, in their funding decisions, the Government have a precise idea of how much it costs to run a museum. I understand that financial reporting by national museums to the Government is carried out in a manner prescribed by the department—and that may itself so inform government that they do know. But confirmation by the Minister would be welcomed. Given the vogue word "sustainability", it would also be helpful to know how the Government expect museums to carry out their capital programmes.

Fifthly, I understand that, before the advent of the Internet the number of bookshops in this country remained magically and mysteriously constant, so that if one closed in Penzance one week, you could be sure that another would open in Tunbridge Wells the next week. So, in the same way, free entry may enlarge visitor numbers at individual museums but the number of visitors overall remains approximately constant. If so, perhaps the visual arts are not yet as embedded in our national consciousness as is music.

However, a perhaps more interesting question than the numbers is the quality of the experience and how one measures it. Here I share a second encapsulation from the Ditchley conference. First, you can measure the soul out of an organisation; secondly, passion is not included in the indices; thirdly, a close link between measurement and money is detrimental—museums might be more adventurous if the link were not quite so direct; and, fourthly, comparability between institutions is key.

I should be interested in the Minister's view of how quality of experience is currently measured at a level above the cleanliness of loos and the quality of coffee shops, although of course I agree with my noble friend Lord Eccles of the importance of both. And indeed, those requests of the Minister brings me happily to Ministers themselves.
In her personal introduction to the recent DCMS document which has been quoted, Estelle Morris, soon happily to join us in your Lordships' House, began her final paragraph with the warming words:
"We in government are passionate about the importance of our cultural heritage".

I am profoundly sure that in Estelle Morris's case that is personally and enthusiastically true. She was of course a teacher for many years. Passion matters. But those who choose Ministers for the DCMS should be aware that cultural constituencies can quickly detect which Ministers are both passionate and knowledgeable and which are simply mouthing communications put into their mouths by officials.

Indeed, there is sometimes a sense that the department is preoccupied with arguing insistently about de minimis questions at the margins when what might be better called for is a comprehensive championing of culture at large, and the arts in particular. Perhaps I may give an instance from the past. When the Royal Academy felt obliged to sell its great cartoon of the Madonna, the then Prime Minister, Harold Macmillan, suggested to my late noble kinsman, who was the first Chief Secretary to the Treasury, that the two of them should go down one lunchtime to the National Gallery where the cartoon was on show to see it with their own eyes. After they had gazed at it for an appropriate period, the Prime Minister said to his Chief Secretary, "And now that we have seen it, how are we going to persuade the Chancellor"—who, parenthetically, was Selwyn Lloyd—"that we should buy this for the nation?". That was leadership from the top of the highest order.

My noble friend Lord Eccles referred to the Goodison review. In an era when so many of the problems of museums would be alleviated by the discharge of philanthropy, I hope the Government will find it within themselves in due course, as my noble friend said, to deliver a proper response to the Goodison review, which was of course only carried out at the Government's invitation.

Acquisitions march with capital expenditure as the areas where the Government do not feel any obvious obligation to be helpful or generous, although I give them considerable credit for their handling of gifts in lieu of tax. I can understand any government blenching at serial requests for help to keep great objects in this country, but I should be interested to learn from the Minister how far there exists a comprehensive compendium of gaps in the collections of individual museums, since it is the filling of gaps which will make our museums even better educational resources than currently. That process requires deliberate focus.

If at one end we are genuinely seeing green shoots of new philanthropy, at the other we must help to ensure that all museums which wish to develop fund-raising departments are assisted to do so, including perhaps collaboratively in the same way as nine museums in Lancashire are co-operating where specific services or expertise can be provided more economically across their group than in museums individually. That is particularly so in the development field, where the land has to be tilled and the seed sown before any financial harvest can be seen or enjoyed.

On access, of course I applaud efforts to introduce to museums people within our various communities who have never been to them before, but I suggest, diffidently, that one way of achieving that is to introduce representatives of those communities not only into the full-time staff of museums, but also and in particular among volunteers.

However, as in all human groups, it is the leadership of the museum sector that is critical to its advance. I applaud Vivien Duffield's impressive training initiative, over which Mr Chris Smith, soon to join us, presides, just as he now does over the Wordsworth Trust, but I cannot help wondering whether there is not a niche for opportunity for briefer, smaller-scale but high-class training schemes locally applied, as in the Lancashire example that I cited.

In the mean time, to revert to the allusions of my noble friend Lord Eccles to a trustee mode, one of the greatest attractions of that mode occurs in the local authority sector, where one can overcome the problems of the museum hierarchy through that method, where the head of a great museum in a great city can sometimes only be an assistant-director because of his reporting relationship to the director of leisure and tourism in that city.

For those of us who are passionate about museums of every size and description, the debate has been a delight and, I hope, may soon become a quarry. The late and much lamented Conrad Russell's father always used to say that there were no circumstances in which he would not be actively cheered up by the offer of a chocolate peppermint cream. For myself, although I acknowledge particular pleasures in particular museums, the possibility of visiting a museum has the same effect on me as chocolate peppermint creams had on the late Bertrand Russell.

I am already looking forward to the time when we will discuss this subject again and my one regret is that I have never visited the cathedral on the Continent of whose treasury the late Douglas Woodruff said that it had the unique characteristic not only of possessing the skull of the infant Samuel but the skull of Samuel as an old man as well.

My Lords, it has been a fascinating debate. It is not often in this House, first, that one has to follow the noble Lord, Lord Brooke, which is always difficult; but also that one thinks that one would like to have a rather longer debate. We have had some excellent, well-informed speeches and I congratulate the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, on initiating the debate and for the speech that he made to start it off in such informative way.

I declare a great personal enthusiasm for museums and galleries. I am very lucky to have a young son who enjoys going to them. When I totted up the galleries and museums that I visited just in recent months, it was a pretty long list. It included the Science Museum, the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Natural History Museum, the British Museum, the Tate Modern, the National Maritime Museum, the Royal Observatory, the Horniman Museum, the National Portrait Gallery, the Imperial War Museum, the Dulwich Picture Gallery and Kew Gardens.

I do not think that that is particularly untypical. People may see them over a rather longer period when they do not have a seven year-old son who likes going to museums, but I am sure that everyone has their own personal favourites among museums. Indeed, I believe that Mark Fisher has even published a book of 1,000 best museums, so he must be congratulated. I certainly need to read it to see whether he agrees with my conclusions.

Without being invidious, my favourite is probably the "Earthquake" exhibition in the Natural History Museum and the mummy lectures, where they have X-rays of mummies, in the British Museum, which was very timely as it took place just before I went to Egypt. That is the kind of thing that can really inspire enthusiasm, and certainly did among my family. Most recently, last weekend, I visited the Cabinet War Rooms, where the new Churchill museum is situated. That is absolutely stunning. It is a real hidden secret within about five minutes from here. The modern technology displays there are quite extraordinary and I recommend a quick trot across the road.

I pay tribute to those Peers who are trustees and board members of museums, especially those who carry considerable responsibility, and also to trustees generally, who give up an enormous amount of their time on a voluntary basis for the well-being of those museums. It is one thing being a consumer—indeed, an enthusiastic visitor and participator, such as me—but it is quite another to scratch below the surface and to be responsible, as a trustee, a board member or a policy-maker, and to see what impact government policy is having on museums and consider how we ensure that they thrive in their activities.

We need to understand the massive contribution that museums—national, regional and local—make to our national life. I was especially impressed by A Manifesto for Museums published last year by the Museums Association, the MLA, the museums' directors and others, which sets out very clearly what museums contribute. In his speech, the noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave, mentioned the number of visitors—the percentage of adult residents in the UK who visit museums and the number of children who visit museums. The figure that he did not mention was the massive increase in public satisfaction about museums. That is not common in many institutions. We should also pay tribute to the National Lottery and the Heritage Lottery Fund which, over the years, have helped us massively to improve the quality of exhibits and produced some very exciting extensions to our national museums.

One element highlighted by A Manifesto for Museums was the fact that museums are a key centre for learning. The noble Lord, Lord Faulkner, emphasised that in his speech. My offices are bang next door to the Museum of London, next to the foot bridge that connects one half of London Wall to the other. Every day, you see schoolchildren traipsing over that bridge and you know that they will have a good experience there. There is a regular flow of schoolchildren and those visits are vital. It is vital to introduce children to museums, to different ideas and historical and cultural influences, as many noble Lords have said. Museums are the most highly valued source of information—well above newspapers and the Internet. It is a horrible phrase, but there are 100 million educational sessions a year. That is very high.

Then we have the economic impact of museums. Several noble Lords alluded to that. The benefits in pure economic terms alone are impressive—about £2 billion in overall economic impact; and the sector employs more 40,000 people. Turning to travel and tourism, the prime reason for many people to come to London is because of our museums. Four out of the top tourist attractions—I think that this figure was also mentioned—are museums. The Tate Modern is the world's most popular gallery of modern art in the world, so it is clearly a major magnet to London. When we consider that we have a massive tourism deficit—putting it bluntly, about £17 billion in the difference between the outflow of British tourists and the inflow of foreign tourists—our museums are crucial in helping us to move towards balance.

Then there is museums and regeneration. You have only to look at the way that the Tate in Liverpool had a huge impact on regeneration. A Manifesto for Museums also makes points about museums being civic and community spaces and catalysts for creativity. They are centres for research and innovation and agents for social change, promoting inter-cultural understanding. That is also extremely important and an increasing area of interest for museums.

Finally, the international aspect is becoming of increasing importance. When I talked to the British Museum in preparation for this debate, it talked about its Africa project, which encourages links with African curators, helps to train them, build their skills and, indeed, will result in the British Museum putting on a big exhibition in Nairobi in Kenya next year. That will be an extremely important exchange of artifacts from Britain with Kenya. That will help cultural understanding and be a great partnership between the British Museum and the Kenyan Government.

The Government published their document in January. Rightly, it raises several issues surrounding citizenship and museums; the fact that the public are demanding a more rich experience from museums; and the whole issue of access and innovation. One of the key things that museums do that we must ensure that we allow them to is to create communities of interest, but we also have the research and scholarship functions, which must co-exist with some of the more, if you like, commercial functions of museums. There are many competing attractions in museums.
Some of the press gave the DCMS a hard time about some of the language in the report. Perhaps phrases such as:
"Collections are at the heart of everything museums do"
and,
"Museums are the way we connect our past with our present"
are slightly platitudinous, but it was good that the DCMS put together a document.

There are some ominous aspects to the document. On measuring cultural value, the noble Lord, Lord Brooke, had it absolutely right when he said that you cannot measure passion. Looking at paragraph 85, if we are not careful the DCMS will impose something similar to NHS targets. That is a slightly worrying trend, so I hope that the Minister will assure us that the Government are not about to introduce targets, statistics and measurability to determine whether museums do a good job.

Seriously, how practical is the document in dealing with issues arising from the activities of museums? I am not totally convinced. I could go into areas with which I do not believe the department has come to grips—for instance, the return of major works of art, major exhibits and the virtual aspect of museums, on which we must make big advances.

In the last few remaining minutes I wish to address funding, on which there were alarming headlines in December. It has been very interesting to hear from the noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave. We have had some great advances. There have been increases in admissions of 71 per cent in the National Museum of Science and Technology, 96 per cent in the Natural History Museum and 113 per cent in the V&A. We all take delight in the fact that the free-admission policy has resulted in many more visitors.

However, are our major museums being compensated adequately for the removal of admission charges? The formula is probably correct but the root of the problem is the core funding available. It does not take a statistician to work out that cost-of-living rises do not compensate adequately for wage increases, which take place at a faster rate. Those are the facts. Museums are not being compensated adequately in that respect. It is worrying when a major institution such as the National Museum of Science and Technology faces the possibility of having to dispose of its major library—I know that a review is ongoing.

I am very pleased that the Chancellor found a way forward on Gift Aid. We all welcomed that. Yet the authors of A Manifesto for Museums claim that an extra £115 million per annum is required to provide adequately for museums' needs. I hope that the Minister will address that. Like the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, I also hope that he will address the Goodison report, a major document to which the Government have not responded.

My Lords, I thank my noble friend Lord Eccles for introducing this timely debate. I was particularly interested in his focus on enjoyment of museums because we sometimes forget that it is an important part of why we go. Obviously, we go to learn, for scholarship and for lots of other reasons, but enjoyment is an important part if we are to encourage more visitors to museums.

The noble Viscount talked about the Bowes Museum, which, although a regional museum, has a collection of national importance, as referred to by my noble friend Lord Brooke. My noble friend Lord Eccles talked about the tax regime available under the current Government, which is helpful to museums.

The noble Lord, Lord Faulkner, talked about the National Railway Museum, and the noble Lord, Lord Addington, talked about the museums that he had been to and their value. We cannot underestimate the value of museums, whatever they may be, large or small. My noble friend Lord Waldegrave is responsible for the National Museum of Science and Technology, an extremely important national museum—it is important to the economy and tourism. I hope that the Minister will address the noble Lord's extremely important point about the strain that the Olympic bid may put on the DCMS's budget.

My noble friend Lord Brooke of Sutton Mandeville was a distinguished Secretary of State for National Heritage—I say that for no other reason than that I was his Minister in this House, and on his behalf I took through the original lottery Bill. One day we may be able to return the National Lottery to what it was supposed to be, as opposed to all the other things the Government have done over the years, which have raped and pillaged some of the funding, to the detriment of the arts and museums.

The noble Lord, Lord Clement-Jones, gave an impressive list of museum visits but he has many more to do. In this country there are nearly 600 independent museums, 530 local authority museums, 134 National Trust museums, 87 armed services museums, 57 university museums, various English Heritage museums and 32 national museums. There are a huge number of museums in this country; they are an important part of our life.

The Government's introduction of free admission to national museums has been a great success. We must commend them on their courage to do it and on putting in place the funding to enable it to happen. Free entry has succeeded in attracting a wider audience, a more diverse range of visitors, but it continues to put funding pressure on museums so that the grant in aid properly compensates them for the considerable increase in costs resulting from the increased number of visitors.

The important question, which my colleague in another place Hugo Swire asked and the noble Lord, Lord Clement-Jones, echoed is: have the Government adequately compensated national museums for either their loss of revenue caused by losing entrance fee charges or the increased cost of coping with the extra visitors? The jury is out; we cannot say, but there are some indications that it is not the case. The Science and Technology Museum is concerned that its funding has not kept up. I know that the Government do not want that to happen, but by nature the Treasury always wants to look for savings and departments always ask for more.

It is important that funding remains sufficient if we are to continue free entry, which has been enormously successful and has resulted in many more visitors. The number of children visiting has increased by 80 per cent, or 3.5 million, since the introduction of free entry. That is extremely important. The DCMS annual report shows that nearly 1 million more people from less privileged backgrounds have visited since 2002, and it continues to want to broaden access. That is extremely important. One must compliment the Government and give them credit where they deserve it. But we must be careful about the term "social inclusion" because it sometimes implies that these are special areas to which the Government will reach out, and sometimes I worry that that means just excluding the rest of us so that the focus becomes too narrow. It must be broad.

There are still concerns about the national galleries. I note that concerns were raised in the National Museum Directors' Conference about the Government asking museums to pursue so many differing, exacting new objectives. We must ensure that, if museums are asked to do that, they have the funding to manage.

My noble friend Lord Eccles asked about the Goodison report, an extremely important report which I read with some care last night. In all the report makes 43 recommendations. I do not expect that the Minister will give us an answer to all of those but perhaps he can answer the specific question that my noble friend Lord Eccles asked on recommendation 8 and give us some idea of the Government's reaction to the report—the areas where he agrees or disagrees.

My noble friend was concerned also about the Heritage Lottery Fund, which he asked the Minister about. I suppose that at this stage I should declare an interest. I am a trustee of the Stanley Spencer Gallery in Cookham, which has recently put in a grant application to the Heritage Lottery Fund. We wait to see what we will get. It is an extremely small museum: one room that contains pictures by one artist, Stanley Spencer. It is located in the village where he spent most of his life and most of his time painting. We are an exclusive collection but we try to be as inclusive as possible by encouraging the maximum number of people to visit. Between 12,000 and 14,000 people visit annually; the numbers does not seem to vary. It is all privately funded and we charge a very modest admission. Anyway, that is my interest to declare.

The noble Lord, Lord Evans, is in his place. Some of the homework that I did for this debate—I do not have much time to go through it now—was to read his report, Renaissance in the Regions, on English museums. It is an extremely thorough and interesting report and goes into great deal about the fact that museums are the most popular attractions in this country. It also goes into all the funding aspects. I noted that he was particularly concerned about the fact that when local authorities come under funding pressure, museums are often the first thing they look to cut. It is an important point.

The noble Lord's report recommended the re-creation of the network of regional hubs. Perhaps the Minister can say something about that, and about the current situation and whether it is a success. I looked at the website and saw that 10 or 12 hubs have been created. It would be useful to know whether there will be any more or whether that is it, and whether the Minister is satisfied with their progress.

The noble Lord's report also talked about partnerships between local and national museums, which is very important. As we know, many of the larger museums have in their collections objects that are not seen for many years but are simply hidden away. His report is also about scholarship, another important issue.

As for the result of the noble Lord's report, he is able to dig his noble friend on the Front Bench in the ribs and ask, "What about it?" His report contains 11 recommendations. I am sure that he knows much better than I do how many of those recommendations have been accepted by his noble friend. The rest of us perhaps do not know, but it would be useful to have some indication.

Before the debate I looked up each party's manifesto on the arts. I apologise that I did not look up the Liberal Democrats' manifesto. However, I did look up my own party's manifesto, which is important, and then looked up the Labour Party's manifesto. I was pleased to note that our manifesto on the arts was twice as long as Labour's. Disappointingly, I have to admit that theirs was one and a half lines and ours was only three lines. However, we published a more detailed document, Action on Arts & Heritage, which contained a number of more detailed and important commitments.

I end by saying that we believe that the arts and heritage are vital parts of any civilised society. We want culture to be at the heart of British life and we recognise the Government's role in supporting and encouraging culture—whatever it may be, whether museums, galleries or the arts—through public funding.

However, it is important to understand that there is a difference between public support and political control. Our museums and galleries excel when they are given the freedom to do so. Too much government interference in our culture, museums and galleries can stifle creativity and erode freedom in society. It is important that the department is not too prescriptive. I think that that is the message that has been echoed by all those who have spoken today.

My Lords, I share with all noble Lords who have spoken in the debate gratitude to the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, for raising such an important issue. He has given us a chance to explore—all too briefly, but all too accurately—the issues. My problem is that, at the last count, I have been asked more than 60 questions, whereas I have only 20 minutes in which to construct a reply. I therefore apologise if I appear a little hurried in some areas.

I am delighted to see that the noble Viscount, Lord Astor, has moved from the transport brief to the transports of delight represented by the DCMS brief. I assure him that our manifesto was fairly brief on the arts because of the old Wren motto; "look around you" if you want to see what we stand for on the arts and our achievements in these years. I think that the debate has enabled noble Lords, in all fairness, to pay tribute to the substantial progress in recent years. I pay tribute in particular to two colleagues who will join us in the near future, Chris Smith and Estelle Morris, neither of whom currently are right honourable Members of the other place. They are in limbo but will shortly join us. I hope we will have the benefit of their contribution to our next debate on this important subject. I am sure that we will all welcome that.

There is an element of contradiction between the concern that the department ought not to be too controlling in its approach to the museum sector—I fully share and understand that point; it is deeply appreciated—and the demand and constant pressure from all sides for increased resources. It is inevitable that the department will have to meet certain criteria in its allocation. On the most general point of all, however, I reassure the House that the department and the Government value the contribution that museums and art galleries make to our national life.

I shall make an obvious point. I think that the noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave, raised it in his constructive contribution. One of the reasons why the Olympic Committee made it fairly clear that bids from provincial cities in Britain would be unlikely to succeed was the overwhelming value that the rest of the world puts on London's resources as a capital city. One can think of a range of resources where, as the Olympic Committee made pretty clear, there are deficiencies in resources. I should add, however, that the most recent evaluation of the bid indicates that we have put right those deficiencies. That is why we are so optimistic.

We pride ourselves on London's enormous cultural strength—its galleries and museums. They are the greatest national asset. I defy anyone to find a visitor to this city who does not emphasise that strength. People come to London for a range of reasons—on business or to play a specific role—but the vast majority of visitors to this country regard London's cultural provision as a great draw. That is why we have such staggering figures for attendance at the National Gallery and all the other major London galleries and museums.

I appreciate the generous comments of the noble Viscount, Lord Astor, and other speakers in the debate. We take pride in the improvement in the figures in recent years. I therefore believe that the anxieties expressed in the debate are the anxieties of success. They are a recognition that the free museums policy has increased patronage by substantial numbers. The noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave, gave those figures in great detail, and it is not for me to repeat them, except to say that they emphasise the extent to which our population is increasing its use of museums and art galleries—both adults and children. Although in certain respects the next generation is not strong in terms of behaviour, let us look at the positive side too; namely, that we see extraordinarily large numbers of young people going to major exhibitions.

That has necessitated substantial increased investment. I will give the most basic figure on that, and, as I said, the noble Lord gave us some very useful figures. We have increased expenditure from £241 million in 1998 to £423 million for 2007. That is a substantial commitment of resources. I understand the anxieties, expressed in many parts of the House, about whether those resources are sufficient to keep us running against the background of the increased number attending at present, when we anticipate increased demands for the future. If policies for increased participation are successful, there will be demands. That is why I want to give assurances.

The noble Lord, Lord Clement-Jones, was perhaps a little uncharitable in his approach. Of course we cannot foresee the budgets beyond 2007 and 2008, because they are only projections that we are working to at present. I want him to understand, however, that we have in place a structure for consultation with museums that will improve relationships with the departments, and a structure for the delivery of funds. The development of the Renaissance project means that we can address the issues of regional museums and the hub structure more effectively.

Some of the most striking increases in attendance have been at regional museums. I am conscious that a number of noble Lords who have spoken in the debate are from the London area—not all—but I emphasise that, just as London benefits hugely from such facilities, the regeneration of many of our major cities in recent years can be measured significantly in terms of their cultural development.

I recently went to Newcastle and was struck by the fact that the changing face of the city related to the increased cultural facilities there—the Sage in Gateshead and the Baltic Exchange. The significance of architecture in regeneration is also not to be underestimated. That is also true for Liverpool, our emerging City of Culture, a position that it will take up in 2008. That city too is showing enormous development with regard to its museums and art galleries. It should be recognised that we are not just being London-centred when looking at the improvements in investment and development in recent years.

I recognise that a debate of this kind is meant to pose questions, and I will address myself to some of the key ones. The Goodison report was addressed in the opening speech by the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, and commented on by a number of subsequent speakers. In certain crucial areas, we intend to fulfil some of the recommendations. Annual funding will double by 2007–08. I have just mentioned the Renaissance programme for regional museums, and I am grateful to my noble friend Lord Faulkner for bringing to our attention one of the most successful: he talked about the development of Shildon, an exciting recent innovation. None of us would underestimate the significance of the National Railway Museum at York as one of the great museums of our country, capable of attracting visitors in their thousands.

The free access commitment, which covers the main national museums and galleries, and the VAT refund scheme that helps deliver free access will be extended to university museums and galleries. There was an issue with regard to the Goodison report about the 50-year rule for export licences. We do not intend to change that rule. We recognise the strength of the arguments on one side, but we need to strike a balance between the need to preserve our heritage and the interests of owners, and the need for the art trade to move items without excessive bureaucracy.

On the issue raised in the Goodison report of the financial implications of the transfer of export licensing and cultural property functions to the MLA, of course there are one-off costs involved, and they are of some significance, but we are providing the necessary support for that. We regard the savings that would be made from that transfer as being helpful in those terms.

Reference was made to the location of the Export Licensing Unit and whether it would be moved outside London. We will bear the issue of costs in mind when we move the unit. On the impact of the transfer of the export licensing service to the MLA and how that was communicated to the effective sectors, we have been in full consultation.

We recognise that the Goodison report is a significant and salient document and one that helps to guide issues of policy. The noble Lord, Lord Brooke, raised the issue of the costs of running a museum. I am well aware of the fact that the department cannot look totally sympathetic in all circumstances because of the constraints on budgets, but we want to develop additional funding in the present spending review in order to improve the position with regard to buildings.

Quality is an age-old problem. The use of the slide rule potentially destroys enjoyment, passion and commitment. How does one measure the qualities of a service? We have to strike a balance with resources that enables us to measure comparative success across the country. I am shying away and trying to reassure the noble Lord, Lord Clement-Jones, that we are not into the issue of health service targets and the detail he has apostrophised with regard to that service—sometimes less than fairly, but at other times with some accuracy.

We have to have some clear measurement of effective investment, which is why we are concerned to increase the degree of co-operation with the regional hubs and to work in consultation with local museums, supporting them and giving the department a clearer understanding of how those museums are working and where support could be best and most effectively given.

The noble Lord, Lord Brooke, asked where the gaps lay in museum collections. That is a crucial issue, which has been studied by our recent working party of the Museums Association. Its report is due next week. We look forward to its arrival, and we shall study the conclusions with great care. I am grateful to the noble Lord for having identified an important area to which we need to attend.

The noble Lord, Lord Addington, also drew attention to the need for continuing investment. Of course he is right to say that the great danger is that the successes may outrun the budgets that have been provided for the developments. I merely seek to assure the House that the Government have a clear priority to make free access to museums work and to encourage wider participation.

Reference has also been made to the educational function of museums and art galleries. That is a crucial part of the Government's overall strategy. Next week, we shall enjoy an opportunity to debate urban regeneration and the arts, and we shall be able to revisit the issue in additional depth. However, there is no doubt that if we want to improve educational achievement and to tackle social exclusion, our museums have a significant role to play. We are committed to ensuring that they have the resources to do so.

I am conscious that the debate has highlighted an area that forms only a small part of the national budget, but one that is very important to the educational, welfare and cultural budget of the nation. Therefore the sector is attracting increased attention from the Government. Within a month, we shall know whether the bid for the Olympic Games has been successful. That will occasion a substantial generation of resources towards facilities in London. It will also mean that we will need to build on and maintain the successes of our museums and art galleries, so that London is presented as the great host city of the games, if that proves to be the case. I emphasise that the bid would provide an opportunity for generating an additional commitment of resources that the Government will consider keenly if—when—the result in a month's time proves to be favourable.
My Lords, I am sorry to press the Minister, but does that mean that he is giving us the assurance that the noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave, was asking for and is of some concern to museum directors?

My Lords, I am not tying investment in museums with the question of the success of the London bid. Rather, I seek to build on the point made by noble Lords around the House: the capital city needs to nurture, cherish and develop its cultural resources because they make it the focal point that it is. That will be further emphasised if we are successful in the bid for the Olympic Games.

I want to establish for noble Lords that our commitment to the development of resources for the museums and art galleries of this country, at national and local level, is an important one. We have already indicated the nature of the resources that we intend to devote to it up to 2007, and further demands on the budget will be addressed sympathetically.

In that framework, I emphasise that we are concerned that institutions should be run effectively. I was pleased to note that several noble Lords declared their interests by indicating that they were trustees of significant institutions. The noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, is chairman of the Bowes Museum. We look on trusteeship as an important form of institutional governance for museums because it means that the department can play its proper role, allocating the available resources as accurately as it can while operating at arm's length from individual institutions. I take the point made by the noble Lord, Lord Waldegrave, that the independence of trustees changed their relationship with other bodies. The noble Lord, Lord Brooke, also stressed that point in the context of local authorities.

The trustee structure enables the arm's-length relationship to be maintained and thus, I hope, allays the fears voiced by the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, in his opening remarks that the department might be involved in heavy-handed measuring, and thus become caught up in an exercise of heavy and intense bureaucracy. That is not the model that we seek to develop in our relationship with institutions, not least because it is clear that one does not need to be heavy-handed with institutions that have been so successful in responding to increased resources by introducing highly successful policies that encourage people to attend and value exhibitions, permanent and temporary, on a scale that we have never seen before. Where the Government have made available additional resources, the institutions have responded across the range with considerable enthusiasm.

I am grateful to all noble Lords who have spoken in the debate. Again I apologise that I have not been able to cover the myriad points raised, but clear themes have emerged. The noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, deserves our gratitude for bringing forward this important issue.

My Lords, I apologise for intervening at the end of the Minister's remarks when I was not able to listen to the whole debate, but I understand that the topic I wish to approach him on has not been covered.

The Minister may have seen last week in the newspapers an article by the director of the British Museum on the assurances given by the Government at the time of the invasion of Iraq that funds would be made available for the reconstruction of Iraq's cultural heritage. He will be aware that the British Museum sent a mission to Iraq with a view to establishing what needed to be done, in the hope that a plan might be developed in conjunction with the Iraqi cultural authorities that would be funded in part by the United Kingdom.

Can the noble Lord tell us whether any additional funding has been made available to the British Museum for that purpose, or whether the Government are considering any such funding? If not, how do they think Iraq will ever recover its pre-eminence in the Middle East in its museums and cultural arts heritage?

My Lords, I apologise to the noble Lord. I recognise the importance of the point that he raises, and I do not doubt that it is relevant to the expenditure commitments of my department. However, we have had a debate that has had a coherence to it because Members of the House have addressed themselves to a range of discrete issues introduced by the noble Viscount, Lord Eccles, and to which I have sought to respond. The matter raised by the noble Lord is somewhat extraneous to this debate. I regret to say that I am not briefed on it. A careful look at the subject matter of the debate shows that it would be surprising if I had been asked about it. A little forewarning might have meant that I would have been able to respond, but, I regret, I am not briefed to give him an intelligent response at this juncture.

My Lords, just before we finish, would the Minister be kind enough to write to me on the subject of the directions from the DCMS to the National Heritage Memorial Fund and thus to the Heritage Lottery Fund under its Acts of Parliament?

My Lords, I have sought to indicate in broad terms the light touch adopted by the department. We have never received a complaint from the National Heritage Memorial Fund about a heavy-handed approach adopted by the department. It is not the department's role to direct, but rather from to time to indicate where the priorities lie. Decisions are taken by the Heritage Lottery Fund on an independent basis. During our time in government, we have not done anything to change the structure of that relationship. However, I shall be only too pleased to respond more fully in writing to the noble Lord.

My Lords, I thank all Members who made such wide-ranging and interesting contributions to the debate. I also thank the Minister for the replies he gave to the points raised. I beg leave to withdraw the Motion for Papers.
Motion for Papers, by leave, withdrawn.

rose to ask Her Majesty's Government, further to the report of the Joint Committee on Human Rights on deaths in custody (3rd Report, Session 2004–05, HL Paper 15), what plans they have to reduce the number of deaths in custody.

My Lords, it is a great privilege for me to open this debate, which I do with some diffidence. I was not personally involved with the bulk of work that led to the report. I joined the Joint Committee on Human Rights at the end of the process. I am therefore particularly grateful that so many other distinguished members of the committee from this House will be speaking.
I am also exceptionally glad that the debate has provided an opportunity for the noble Lord, Lord Ramsbotham, to make his first contribution in the House.

We are debating a report from the Joint Committee on Human Rights, a committee of both Houses which was chaired from its establishment until the end of the last Session by Jean Corston from the other place. She was the founding chairman and a most esteemed and successful one. We shall benefit greatly when she joins us in the House, as we shall from the arrival of David Chidgey, also a past member of the committee.

Sometimes questions of human rights observance can seem obscure and legalistic. This report is not about anything obscure or legalistic. It is about human rights at its most immediate and universal. It is about the right to life enshrined in Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
It is also a report full of tragedies because it concerns people—mainly distressed people in need of care—who have lost their lives, and lost them while in the care of state agencies.

However, the report is not only a chronicle of tragedies and a critique of processes. It goes much further. It seeks to show how an important human rights principle—the right to life—needs to be understood and implemented in everyday practice. It exemplifies a human rights approach which is not a "be careful or you might be caught out" approach. Protecting the right to life is a positive requirement that should guide policy and practice at all levels. It should help all staff who are responsible for locking up their fellow human beings to understand what the priorities of their job are and to know when they have done well.

There is no time in a debate of this nature to give a full account of the committee's report, its conclusions and all its recommendations. I would strongly recommend the report as well worth reading in its entirety. We are grateful to the very expert staff who serve the Joint Committee with so much dedication. Clearly for them this work is not just a job.

I shall concentrate now on the main conclusions and recommendations of the report itself and the government response, published by the committee in March 2005. My summary of the committee's conclusions and recommendations will be very brief. We said that there are more people than ever in custody and many of them should not be there. The conditions in which they are held are bad for them, overcrowded and far from home. Many of them have acute special needs, such as mental health and substance abuse problems. They are exceptionally vulnerable and should be held elsewhere.

The people who look after them on our behalf are under great pressure and are not properly trained for what they have to do. Mentally ill people are being held in prison because there are not enough secure psychiatric places.

The result of all these factors is a failure on the part of the state to meet the duty of care required for compliance with Article 2. As stated in paragraph 372 of the report, the heart of the problem is a,
"misplaced over-reliance on the prison system . . . the imprisonment of such vulnerable people is at the root of the problem itself".

The report is not only concerned with prison deaths. It notes the high level of mental health problems among those who die in police custody and the need for training and professional support for police custody officers. It comments on the inappropriate use of police cells rather than hospitals as places of safety under Section 136 of the Mental Health Act 1983.
